Abstract

This study explores the application of diffusion models in the field of typhoons, predicting multiple ERA5 meteorological variables simultaneously from Digital Typhoon satellite images. The focus of this study is Taiwan, an area highly vulnerable to typhoons. By comparing the performance of Conditional Denoising Diffusion Probability Model (CDDPM) with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Squeeze-and-Excitation Networks (SENet), the results show that CDDPM performs best in generating accurate and realistic meteorological data. Specifically, CDDPM achieved a PSNR of 32.807, which is approximately 7.9% higher than CNN and 5.5% higher than SENet. Furthermore, CDDPM recorded an RMSE of 0.032, showing an 11.1% improvement over CNN and 8.6% improvement over SENet. A key application of this research is for imputation purposes in missing meteorological datasets and generating additional high-quality meteorological data using satellite images. It is hoped that the results of this analysis will enable more robust and detailed forecasting, reducing the impact of severe weather events on vulnerable regions. The code is accessible at https://github.com/TammyLing/Typhoon-forecasting.

Introduction

In recent years, the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events have increased due to the impacts of global climate change. Typhoons, one of the types of tropical cyclones, receive notable attention due to the harm they cause to both the natural environment and human societies. Taiwan, a major economic hub and populous region in Asia, is particularly significant due to its high vulnerability to typhoons, making it an excellent focus region for this project. With the rapid development of machine learning, typhoon forecasting can be done using various methods. Previous studies have used artificial neural networks to analyze satellite image data and generative adversarial networks to predict typhoon trajectories and cloud structures.

This project builds on these advancements by using Conditional Denoising Diffusion Probability Models (CDDPM) to predict multiple ERA5 reanalysis variables simultaneously, using Digital Typhoon images as conditional inputs. CDDPM has been successfully used in remote sensing previously. The study's contributions can be summarized as follows:

1. A customized typhoon dataset is created, facilitating the matching of DT and ERA5 reanalysis data for any given region, allowing for more accurate forecasting models across various regions.
2. CDDPM is demonstrated to consistently outperform other models across multiple reanalysis variables with the highest PSNR and SSIM scores and the lowest FID and LPIPS scores.
3. The ability to generate additional high-quality reanalysis data from satellite images is demonstrated, which can be used for forecasting and filling gaps in existing reanalysis datasets.

Data

2.1 Datasets

* ERA5 is the fifth-generation ECMWF reanalysis for the global climate from 1940 onwards, provided by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF). In this project, this dataset is used as the model input data, and the variables used are the u-component of wind (u10), v-component of wind (v10), surface pressure (sp), and temperature at 2 meters (t2m) within the latitude and longitude range of 116.0794 - 126.0794 and 18.9037 - 28.9037, respectively, covering an area around Taiwan (±5°).
* The Digital Typhoon Dataset is the largest typhoon satellite image dataset covering the Western North Pacific region from 1978 to 2022, with a high resolution of 5 km and a temporal resolution of 1 hour. For this project, 129 typhoons filtered out from the original collection are used as the target dataset.

2.2 Data Processing

1. Region Selection and Data Extraction: The Taiwan region from 18.9037°N to 28.9037°N and 116.0794°E to 126.0794°E is selected.
